bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 13, 1941

div1.p: Hench is relieved that Kissinger is doing better, and he provides information about the upcoming publication of his yellow fever paper.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 13, 1941
div1.opener:
Aug 12/41
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
August 13, 1941
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am delighted to know that Mr. Kissinger is
improving and under the circumstances I do not blame Mrs.
Kissinger for wanting him kept at home. You were very
kind to help in this matter.

So far as I know, the yellow fever paper will be
in the October number of Hygeia and with my paper there
will be not only a colored reproduction of the painting
but some comments about the painting also. Rest assured
that I will send you as many of these reprints as you
want.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
